flow.descriptionCdata:
1cf22e38-0800-417b-b390-3d20dc6d1feb.08858125-7836-4e27-9bf8-fed40f842081.description=
Accepts an object in the JavaScript Object Notation format (JSON) and
returns a value for the specified key.

The JSON format encodes objects as a set of unordered key/value pairs, which is
similar to a structure or map in other programming languages.  For example,
   { "city" \: "Palo Alto", 
     "state" \: "CA" }
is an object with two elements one with the name "city" having the value "Palo
Alto", and the other being the name "state" with the value "CA". This operation would 
return "Palo Alto" if user enters "city" as a key.

If the input object contains JSON array, array index can be used in the key input. For example, 
{ "location"\: [
      {"city"\: "Roseville", "country"\: "United States"},
      {"city"\: "Cluj", "country"\: "Romania"},
      {"city"\: "Yehud", "country"\: "Israel"}]    
}
The operation would return "Roseville" if user enters "location[0].city" as a key.

JavaScript objects are useful for representing structured data, and are
especially when used within an array.  For example, an operation that retrieves
a set of incidents from an external system may return the entire list in one
array of incident objects.  The description of the enclosing folder,
/Library/Utility Operations/Container/JavaScript Objects has more examples, and
the JSON format is described completely at http\://www.json.org.

Inputs

   object
      The JavaScript object.  
      The operation will return a failure if it is not a JavaScript object.

   key
      The key in the object to get the value of.

Responses

   success
      The value was successfully returned for the specified key. 

   failure
      There was some error in processing the object, most likely because the
      object is not in valid JavaScript Object Notation or the specified key does not exist in the object.  
      You may wish to use a tool such as http\://www.jsonlint.com/ to help diagnose problems with
      JavaScript Object Notation.

Outputs

   The primary output will be the value for the specified key in the object.

Note

    If the value in JSON object is in scientific notation, the returned output will be converted to an equivalent decimal number. Ex, 2.9e+1 will be converted to 29.
1cf22e38-0800-417b-b390-3d20dc6d1feb.2b47c9bc-96dc-48ee-a928-8d577b875d0d.description=
This operation checks whether a string matches another string, using a specific matching rule. The "toMatch" input is the string that is checked for matching the "matchTo" expression. 

Inputs\:
    matchType - The type of match to perform.
Valid values\: Exact Match, Contains, Contains Once, Does Not Contain, Match All Words, Match No Words, Regex
Default value\: Exact Match
    toMatch - The string that is checked for matching.
    matchTo - The string to match against.
Example\: If "matchType" is “RegEx”, the "matchTo" input is a regular expression such as\: ^-?\d+(([\.,]\d+)?)+$. 
    ignoreCase - Specifies whether to ignore case when matching or not.
Valid values\: False, True
Default value\: False

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. It contains the string "Matches" if the "toMatch" string matches the "matchTo" string. Otherwise, it contains the string "Does Not Match".  

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.
1cf22e38-0800-417b-b390-3d20dc6d1feb.8d7d8389-c78e-47ce-8d02-f95f06797baf.description=
This operation checks whether a string matches another string, using a specific matching rule. The "toMatch" input is the string that is checked for matching the "matchTo" expression. 

Inputs\:
    matchType - The type of match to perform.
Valid values\: Exact Match, Contains, Contains Once, Does Not Contain, Match All Words, Match No Words, Regex
Default value\: Exact Match
    toMatch - The string that is checked for matching.
    matchTo - The string to match against.
Example\: If "matchType" is “RegEx”, the "matchTo" input is a regular expression such as\: ^-?\d+(([\.,]\d+)?)+$. 
    ignoreCase - Specifies whether to ignore case when matching or not.
Valid values\: False, True
Default value\: False

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. It contains the string "Matches" if the "toMatch" string matches the "matchTo" string. Otherwise, it contains the string "Does Not Match".  

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.
1cf22e38-0800-417b-b390-3d20dc6d1feb.a637d01c-bf39-41a6-9f73-cb5ac13059cc.description=
Sends an smtp email
 
Input Parameters\:
hostname - hostname or ip address of smtp server
port - port smtp service is listening
from - from email address
to - email address(s) or recipients
subject - email subject
body - body of the email
htmlEmail - true or false, whether the email should be sent supporting html rich email.
readReceipt - true or false, whether or not to request a read receipt
attachments - comma separated list of files to attach (must be full path)
username - if SMTP authentication is needed, the username to send
password - the password to use
characterSet - the character set encoding for the entire email which includes subject, body, attached file name and the attached file. Default value is UTF-8
contentTransferEncoding - the content transfer encoding scheme (such as 7bit, 8bit, base64, quoted-printable etc) for the entire email which includes subject, body, attached file name and the attached file. Default value is - quoted-printable or Q Encoding.
 
 Responses\:
 success - successfully sent the email
 failure - failed to send the email

Note\:
For special characters (East Asian, right-to-left languages, etc.) you must install the support files on your local machine.
	For doing this on Windows go to Control Panel -> Regional and Language Options -> Language and check the options at Supplemental language support.
1cf22e38-0800-417b-b390-3d20dc6d1feb.b5837a32-3c7c-474d-a7aa-7a9fee23edcf.description=
Resolves any Context variables in a String. This is useful if you have an input to a flow that references undefined context variables, and define them later. Pass in the context key name of the string that contains unresolved context variables.

Inputs\:
keyName - The name of the context key that should have its value reresolved.
eraseUnresolved - A boolean value. If true, any unresolved context variable references will be replaced by nothing (IE ${variable} disappears).

Responses\:
success - One or more context variables were replaced, or could not be resolved and were erased from the string.
failure - No context variables were referenced in the string.

Returns\:
The resulting string having had context variable references replaced with the resolved values.
1cf22e38-0800-417b-b390-3d20dc6d1feb.c9dbb442-9a09-4beb-8160-e10128ed8d2a.description=
Accepts an object in the JavaScript Object Notation format (JSON) and

The JSON format encodes objects as a set of unordered key/value pairs, which is

is an object with two elements one with the name "city" having the value "Palo

If the input object contains JSON array, array index can be used in the key input. For example, 
{ "location"\: [

Responses

      The value was successfully returned for the specified key. 

   failure
      There was some error in processing the object, most likely because the

      You may wish to use a tool such as http\://www.jsonlint.com/ to help diagnose problems with
      JavaScript Object Notation.

Note

1cf22e38-0800-417b-b390-3d20dc6d1feb.cb95124c-e8a6-4920-b3f7-4955bf92a8c9.description=
This operation does not do anything. It can be used to filter flow variables by defining them as inputs and filtering them in the Results tab.

Inputs\:
    field1 – An optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
    field2 – An optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
    field3 – An optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
    field4 – An optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. It contains the value of  "field1" as it was specified at input or when filtered. 

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
1cf22e38-0800-417b-b390-3d20dc6d1feb.cd0ed842-69ae-42bb-9575-2523f651422d.description=
Sends an smtp email
 
Input Parameters\:
hostname - hostname or ip address of smtp server
port - port smtp service is listening
from - from email address
to - email address(s) or recipients
subject - email subject
body - body of the email
htmlEmail - true or false, whether the email should be sent supporting html rich email.
readReceipt - true or false, whether or not to request a read receipt
attachments - comma separated list of files to attach (must be full path)
username - if SMTP authentication is needed, the username to send
password - the password to use
characterSet - the character set encoding for the entire email which includes subject, body, attached file name and the attached file. Default value is UTF-8
contentTransferEncoding - the content transfer encoding scheme (such as 7bit, 8bit, base64, quoted-printable etc) for the entire email which includes subject, body, attached file name and the attached file. Default value is - quoted-printable or Q Encoding.
 
 Responses\:
 success - successfully sent the email
 failure - failed to send the email

Note\:
For special characters (East Asian, right-to-left languages, etc.) you must install the support files on your local machine.
	For doing this on Windows go to Control Panel -> Regional and Language Options -> Language and check the options at Supplemental language support.
1cf22e38-0800-417b-b390-3d20dc6d1feb.de17eb78-d2d3-41c1-ba3c-a267ad3c2694.description=
Check to see if the value stored in a specified flow variable, denoted by key, is null.

Inputs\:
keyName - The key to check, i.e. the name of the flow variable.

Returns\: 
The value in the specified key, i.e. flow variable.

Responses\:
isNull - If the key is a null pointer, i.e. the flow variable doesn't have an assigned value.
notNull - If some value is stored in the key, i.e the flow variable has a value assigned.
1cf22e38-0800-417b-b390-3d20dc6d1feb.df5ffc3a-d7d8-4bb5-99fa-9cb75164aea4.description=
This operation checks whether a string matches another string, using a specific matching rule. The "toMatch" input is the string that is checked for matching the "matchTo" expression. 

Inputs\:
    matchType - The type of match to perform.
Valid values\: Exact Match, Contains, Contains Once, Does Not Contain, Match All Words, Match No Words, Regex
Default value\: Exact Match
    toMatch - The string that is checked for matching.
    matchTo - The string to match against.
Example\: If "matchType" is “RegEx”, the "matchTo" input is a regular expression such as\: ^-?\d+(([\.,]\d+)?)+$. 
    ignoreCase - Specifies whether to ignore case when matching or not.
Valid values\: False, True
Default value\: False

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. It contains the string "Matches" if the "toMatch" string matches the "matchTo" string. Otherwise, it contains the string "Does Not Match".  

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.
1cf22e38-0800-417b-b390-3d20dc6d1feb.e0aee1c8-2b20-40ec-941f-0d1c70e98fa2.description=
Check to see if the value stored in a specified flow variable, denoted by key, is null.

Inputs\:
keyName - The key to check, i.e. the name of the flow variable.

Returns\: 
The value in the specified key, i.e. flow variable.

Responses\:
isNull - If the key is a null pointer, i.e. the flow variable doesn't have an assigned value.
notNull - If some value is stored in the key, i.e the flow variable has a value assigned.

flow.name: SA_Attach_CA_Policy

staticBinding.value:
Something went wrong with with attaching a Software Policy or Custom Attribute to a server. Please verify what failed and if it needs to be fixed.

Hostname: ${server.hostname}
Wave: ${key}

Wave: ${key}
